newsitem.title: CANADA: Old system at Toronto bourse can't handle volumes.
newsitem.headline: Old system at Toronto bourse can't handle volumes.

text.p: The Toronto Stock Exchange's antiquated computer trading system collapsed in mid-morning trade on Tuesday, crippled for the second time in as many weeks by trading that exceeded the system's capacity.

The system was down for almost an hour today after crashing minutes after trading in Bre-X Minerals Ltd resumed at 1030 EST/1530 GMT following a day-long halt. A total of 7.78 million shares of the troubled Calgary exploration company changed hands in 22 minutes before the system went down.
On Thursday, the last day Bre-X previously traded, TSE systems went down twice during the session and forced the exchange to close 15 minutes early.
"Both days were associated with huge volumes in the system," TSE spokeswoman Jane Wong told Reuters.
"It's old architecture. It was developed when the volumes here at the TSE weren't as high, so it's not able to handle increased volumes that we're experiencing right now."
Wong said the CATS (Computer Assisted Trading System) was due to be replaced later this year by a system driven by TOREX trading engines supplied by the Paris Bourse.
"When we get our new system up in place, these volumes won't be a problem," said Wong.
Irritated traders in Toronto said the system problems were hurting Canada's reputation as a market player.
"I feel not very good. And neither does the rest of the world," said one trader.
But other traders were taking the collapse in stride.
"(Stuff) happens, there isn't much you can do about it. I don't like it. That's obvious (but) the exchange in the past has had a pretty good record," one trader said.
The TSE system last collapsed in early 1996.
